awd_titl_txt: 2022 AIChE/ASEE Chemical Engineering Summer School: Building the Chemical Engineering Community
awd_abstract_narration:
The American Institute of Chemical Engineers (AIChE) and the American Society for Engineering Education (ASEE) will hold the 17th Chemical Engineering Summer School from July 24-29, 2022, at the Colorado School of Mines in Golden, Colorado. At the behest of AIChE, the Summer School was initiated in 1931 by the Society for the Promotion of Engineering Education, now known as ASEE, to promulgate best practices in chemical engineering education. The Summer School has since been held every five years and continues to be a valuable professional development resource for hundreds of new chemical engineering faculty members. The 2022 Summer School attendees will engage in a half-day Teaching Institute, attend plenary talks, and participate in sessions on pedagogy, diversity and inclusivity, emerging technical topics in the field, and industry-related content. The Summer School agenda includes time for both informal and structured professional networking with other attendees and organizers as well as invited industrial representatives. At the conclusion of the Summer School, attendees will have developed new skills and knowledge to improve their teaching effectiveness and have discovered a peer network with whom they can share new insights and continue to grow as chemical engineering educators. The attendees' early investment in learning effective teaching strategies will manifest benefits with each subsequent cohort of chemical engineering graduates. 

The 2022 Chemical Engineering Summer School emerges from the partnership between the AIChE Chemical Education Division and the ASEE Chemical Engineering Division to provide new faculty members with effective teaching strategies. The Summer School is a unique professional development opportunity for new chemical engineering faculty and builds upon a model that has been successful for decades. The Summer School curriculum is rooted in evidence-based teaching practices taught by experienced chemical engineering educators. Attendees are, thus, expected to come away from the Summer School having developed their teaching portfolios, strategies for adopting active and cooperative learning in courses, as well as an understanding of how to assess student performance and outcomes and to use this information to improve teaching effectiveness. The Summer School agenda also includes "Industry Day" programming to support effective undergraduate curricula design and to discuss the keys to successful industrial-academic research collaborations. Virtual communities of practice, supported via the AIChE Engage platform, will provide attendees with opportunities to continue sharing and learning best practices with their colleagues for years to come.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The ASEE/AIChE Chemical Engineering Summer School (ChESS) is a week-long, roughly quinquennial over the past nearly 100 years, faculty professional development event bringing together early-career and seasoned faculty for workshops and community building.  The ChESS took place July 25-29, 2022 at the Colorado School of Mines in Golden, Colorado, with 142 participants (from 88 different schools) and 69 presenters and over 30 Industry and Professional Society/Organizations representatives.  

The two core outcomes for the Summer School are to

1)  To build the Chemical Engineering education community, and

2)  To provided useful knowledge and tools for teaching, scholarship, and service for those early in their careers.

At ChESS early career faculty learned best practices in effective teaching, taught by leaders in chemical engineering.  This includes active learning.  Furthermore, the participants also learned about technical topics (such as safety, sustainability, process modeling, hands-on engineering design, and emerging topics within the discipline) and non-technical topics (such as communication skills, teamwork, advising, and DEI & social justice).  The Summer School also aids in the career development of new faculty by providing them extensive resources and networking opportunities.  These new educators were able to form strong partnerships with their peers who are in similar stages of their careers.  In addition, they met and interacted with senior chemical engineering faculty and received critical advise on the trajectories of their careers.  In many ways, the summer school is one of the most valuable experiences in the career of a new faculty member.

The summer school provided over 50 interactive workshops on active learning, technical topics, non-technical topics, and networking events.  Thus, the Summer School has a broad impact, as new faculty become much more effective at educating the next generation of chemical engineers. The participating faculty were asked to present a poster about their research and/or education activities at their home institution. This allowed for introductions between the faculty member and the other attendees but also spurred conversation on several topics.  In addition, new faculty members were invited to join established Virtual Communities of Practice (on core classes and teaching focused faculty (non-tenure track), through the AIChE EdDiv, to continue the exchange of engineering educations best practices. With the support from AIChE EdDiv and ASEE ChED, participants were integrated into one or both larger, sustainable communities to continue to innovate and adapt their teaching beyond the Chemical Engineering Summer School.    

A survey conducted immediately after the close of ChESS 2022 showed respondents found the summer school to be successful at meeting its two goals.  Ninety-six percent of the respondents strongly agreed or somewhat agreed that the Summer School was conductive for meeting other Chemical Engineering faculty, while the same percentage strongly agreed or agreed that the workshops were useful.  Ninety-three percent of the respondents strongly agreed that they would recommend the Summer School to a colleague, with a further 3% expressing agreement.  Although, it was not a goal of ChESS, seventy-three percent of the respondents to the survey conducted immediately after the close of the summer school, indicated that ChESS was good at forming connections to Industry / Professional Societies.
